No one can ever really know what others see.  There are certain conditions where some folks see letters as different colors.  There are folks who have perfect pitch either in hearing singing or both.  Generally we understand colors and sounds but the limits are physical. There are many thing we cannot see or hear.  Electro microscopes show us tiny things.  Polarization is just a “trick” of the light in our brains.  Our brains can be fooled by other things such as weather phenomenon.  Kind of grade school level information.  Most folks had eye tests as kids to check for color blindness by looking at a circle and determine if you see a number or letter or such.   Education in the USA is deteriorating if full grown adults are just learning this now.

All humans (not being blind) can see polarized light as light. Some can see the difference between light being polarized or not. We're not all the same. Most humans see color in three color bands of the humanly visible spectrum of light, some see colors in four bands and another group is color-weak or color-blind. Generally the women that see color in 4 bands have sons that are color blind. As the photosites in the retina are connected in strings to one neuron, there is serious lossy data compression going on in there, and we loose most of the 120 "megapixel" resolution that way. This facilitates a much thinner optical nerve and is why we can rotate our eyes in the socket. When we are born and open our eyes, we must learn to interpret the visual information - e.g. we "see" upside down in vectors, not pixels. If we never learn the importance of seeing the polarized quality of light then we may totally miss it all our lives unless we meet a physics girl.

I am afflicted with astigmatism, a condition where the cornea is not a perfect portion of a sphere, it could be more football shaped or even irregularly varying in surface smoothness or thickness. Glasses can be ground to correct for this condition, but it's complicated and only partially successful. I was into serious table tennis and discovered that the difference between glasses and contact lenses was worth around 6 points per 21 point game, because the contact lenses corrected the astigmatism much better.

A side effect of astigmatism is a polarizing effect, so I grew up assuming everyone could see the stress patterns in transparent objects. Car windows and windshields were particularly filled with annoying stress colors and patterns - to me. When I stopped being serious about TT and also was working in a dusty environment, I stopped wearing contacts and never looked back.

And then I had cataract surgery. The implanted lens would provide me with long focal distance fixed focal length vision, but would not correct for the astigmatism and I would still need glasses, <sigh>. But an option was an implant lens that would also correct for the astigmatism and glasses would only be required for close vision like reading. Great, sign me up. And they were excellent. I have wonderful vision, however I can no longer see the stress patterns. Which has both good and bad points.

LCD polarized screens are a real problem when they are the instruments on a plane or boat where people wear sunglasses a lot and not beaing able to read them could kill you. The most common, but inadequate, solution is just to make sure the screen polarization is always vertical since polarized sunglasses are design to block the horizontally polarized light from water and objects that are horizontal. This doesn't work if you are looking from an angle or turn your head. There is a universal solution which is to place a 1/4 wave plate in front of the screen which rotates the light into circular polarization with half in each direction.

I also observed strange color shift when using a polarized filter on my Praktica VLC2 and VLC3 cameras, as they have semi-transparent mirrors utilizing polarization for light metering purposes. The manual says that linear polarizing filters might affect the accuracy of metering, but I did not observe any noticeable metering error when using them. What I however noticed strongly, was a color shift in the viewfinder, from orange to blue. Of course, the final photograph was not tinted (nor a positive "slide" film, e.g. Velvia). It was just an optical quirk due to polarization and how the system worked (as well as how my eyes worked - how I perceived the image). As far as I know, only the VLC line of Praktica "L" series cameras was affected, as it had exchangeable viewing screens as well as prisms, so the metering was different than other models, and it used polarization of light. I sold most of my old "film" cameras, but kept the VLC2 and VLC3 "flagships" with a couple of M42 lenses. Such "ancient" technology can be great to observe some basic physical laws.

When I did photography I had a collection of polarizing filters for all the different filter thread sizes for my camera lens. Every time I acquired a new camera lens that had different filter sizes, I had to buy two new filters with one A1 sky light to protect the front lens and block UV and a polarizer filter. This always added another $80-$250 to every camera lens purchase price because I only would by German made B+W filters. Polarizing filters for camera lens are made so they can rotate on the front of the camera lens so it can be oriented to block glare to coincide to the orientation of the light source such as the Sun or other point light source. This allows to take pictures though a glass window and capture the subject behind the glass or reduce glare on a reflective surface such as a car, wet pavement, etc. or foliage such grass, trees, or intensify the blue of the sky and add more detail to clouds. What the pretty young Physics Girl didn’t show was how polarizing filters are made. With eye glasses or camera lens filters, are made of three layers. The two outside layers sandwich a middle layer of a corrugated thin transparent film. The corrugations only allows photons traveling in one direction/orientation to pass through while the rest of the scattered photons are blocked. The corrugation is so small measuring in microns that it is beyond the resolution of the human eye, photographic film or photosensors.

Explaining what we know is second prize. Discovering something we don't know is where the action really happens.
Take three pieces of liquid crystal display. Place one on top of the other and rotate until light extinction.
Following so far? Great!
Now take the third piece and place it on top of the other two.
Now, keeping the first two immobile with respect to each other, turn the third piece.

The stack becomes transparent again.
How?
How does light, which was blocked, resume its "journey" post hoc, after it was blocked?
A) Light doesn't travel.
B) The future pulls the present into being. (The three THIN polarized pieces represent a very small period of time at light speed. therefore the third piece is very near in the future, therefore the effect is powerful).
Meaning: we have got cause and effect the wrong way around.

Awesome video. However I have to clear something up; hi, electrical engineer here, electromagnetic waves look nothing like the one flat plane of electric up/down wigglies perpendicular to the one flat plane of magnetic side/side wigglies. The problem with that god damned chart and representation is that it's easy to grasp onto when you aren't familiar with the topic, and all media grabbed onto it at the expense of the larger picture. What that chart is representing is the change in the amplitude (intensity) over time of each of the types of waves, and for mathematical convenience they are shown perpendicular to each other, as the fall in intensity of one type of wave inspires the rise in intensity of the other and vice-versa. What it does show well is the fact that it is self-propagating with no loss as it goes along through the medium it's travelling through. So, trying to picture light waves as + shaped wigglies is really useless when trying to imagine how polarization factors in; really, it's hard to say what it DOES look like, but I had to clear up a widespread misconception about what that specific graphical representation is displaying. Sorry, but light waves do not wiggle left to right or up and down.  The familiar sine wave representation of an electromagnetic wave is merely what appears on an oscilloscope as it measures the intensity of it's electric or magnetic property. When an EM wave passes it is massless and there is nothing "wiggling" left, right, or up, down.  This is just some sort of teaching tool like the image of an electron wizzing around the nucleus like planets orbiting the sun: totally false. Just like the earth sitting in a trampoline image to describe space contraction nearer to earth as an explanation of why things orbit earth: because space is "curved."  Well, maybe so but the image is all wrong because it only shows in in two dimensions when in truth the phenomenon happens in 3.

When the circularly polarised waves E fields align vertically, we perceive a vertically polarised wave. Its still actually composed of TWO circular waves.(even after going through the polariser)
One circular wave interacts with the substance(s) its passing through more than the other one and the travel time is DIFFERENT for them .

Light waves DO NOT "go up and down." Instead, "waves" which are emanated in the electromagnet spectrum (from radio to radar to infrared to colored light to ultraviolent to X-rays and cosmic rays) are actually "pulses" of radiated energy.  On paper, we usually represent the INTENSITY of the wave--as it increases and decreases--as an up and down sine wave. But in reality, the pulses continue in a straight line, so: strong, weak, strong, weak, strong, weak, strong..." We MODEL this on paper by drawing a line going down for weak and going up for strong. The sine wave is a MODEL showing the intensity measurement  oscillating, not the reality of the light wave pulsing.

ok I feel this wasn't explained clearly enough so let me explain:
1. The first polarized film filters the light so they all have the same polarization/direction.
2. The tape then refracts the light differently depending on wavelength/colour, but since they all started out in the same direction all light of the same colour is now twisted the same way.
3. Finally, the second polarizing filter now sorts out the light of one particular direction and since we determined that a particular colour now have a particular orientation, it's going to let through a certain colour.
It's the nanoscopic air-gap that refracts the colours, just like oil on water but since the distance is not perfect and they used more than one layer you will see other colours as well that will have the same orientation but be of a different colour.

I've read (in an astronomy magazine) that human retinas fall on a bell curve, so that maybe 5% or 10% of us can slightly see polarized light because their rods and cones all line up the same way. The rest of us have less and less alignment, until the 5% or 10% on the opposite end of the bell curve can't see ANY polarized light. (That's me.)

For navigation, turn your back to the Sun, and look up at a 45 degree angle up into the sky, and look through polarized lenses. You should see a darker blue area in the sky directly opposite the sun. Turn your head left and right too notice it more easily. Some animals can see this effect.

Some types of 3d cinema projectors use polarization, including the popular "RealD" technology, so you may have a pair of polarizers lying around. What I've read online says that each eyepiece has a circular polarizer (one clockwise and the other counterclockwise) but the ones I have have at least two polarizers sandwiched together: a circular one in front, and a linear one (the same in both eyes) in the back. You can see that the front is circular by looking through them in the mirror: each eye blocks its own reflection, because the mirror reverses the circular polarization. But when you hold them the other way (with the front of the glasses away from the mirror) the light passes through, showing that there is a linear polarizer on that side.

This video brought me back to my minerology days.  The same principal is used in geology for the microscopic study of rock samples as a powerful analytic tool.  A sample of rock is attached to a slide by way of an amorphous clear epoxy, and shaved and ground to a very thin section.  I was taught to use quartz as a standard for when it was thin enough.  Under cross polar lenses (a.k.a crossed nicols,) one above and one below the sample, quartz exhibits a first order grey color.  Because of the properties of light passing through the thin section, a variety of data can be assertained.  This includes the chemistry of the minerals and their molecular structure.

I don't think engineers are using polarimeters for stress analysis anymore. It was a useful tool for creating 2D analysis of complex shapes, but was only for qualitative analysis if I recall correctly. It was also very difficult and expensive because, as shown in the video, any stress in the plastic itself shows up immediately when polarized.  The "stress concentrations" mentioned in the video are stresses locked into the part due to the plastic flowing in the mold, not loads applied afterward.  FEA is vastly better in every way for stress analysis. Similarly, some of my teachers also talked about cutting out complex graphs of functions from aluminum foil and weighing them in vacuum scales to get the integral.  No one would do that anymore either, except as an interesting demonstration like this.

Say that I'm looking at colorful Christmas lights, placed horizontally against the wall, in an otherwise black room. The blue Christmas light appears to visually be above the string, and the red one appears to be below it. And since I suppose pure violet lights are rare, when I look at a purple light, I see a faint purple splotch where it's supposed to be, and a blue and red one. I suppose it's because they're using two light sources and not a "violet light."

So my question is, is this due to some sort of prismatic diffraction going on or something? Or how lenses bend certain colors more than others (why does this not happen with binoculars or telescopes)?

Also why do I see spokes around every light source? I never once have seen bright light without some degree of spokes. Either I see bokeh (no glasses) or spokes. And no matter how much I clean my glasses there are always spokes.

My diopter is -7.5 and -8 so in extremely nearsighted. My new prescription is -9 in one and I think -9.5 in the other (I went to a different doctor which had a more precise measurement).

My glasses always have that thing that makes it thinner due to the high index, transition lenses, and something that makes it shatter-proof, which I think may matter due to materials having different refractive indexes. It also corrects for slight astigmatism.

I used to use polarised light in a lab test when I worked in Quality Control for a factory that made caramel, both as colouring  agents and as dessert sauces, syrups etc. one of the caramels we made  had invert syrup as a base ingredient. It's called 'invert syrup' because when light is shone through it, it twists it in the opposite direction to that 'ordinary syrup' does. Making 'invert syrup' is fairly simple and involves ordinary syrup which is then altered (by chemical means or heat- I can't remember which, now). We knew the reaction had converted the majority of the 'ordinary' syrup to invert only when, on testing in the polarimeter, we got a negative number as a result.

So the tape and the plastics are birefringent. The index of refraction depends on the angle of polarization of the incoming light. The liquid crystals in the LCD display are also birefringent. They surround the liquid crystal with a small electric field to change the crystal's orientation to the polarization filter. By using an electric field to move the liquid crystal around they can allow more or less light through. This is how LCD screens work.

The practical aspect for the injection molds is pretty cool. You touched on it a little bit.  The color bands are kind of like a topographical map, the closer the lines are together the steeper the change in internal stresses.  Not only does this reveal information about how a plastic flows inside a mold, but it also can help reveal how effective a thermal cycle can be (after molding) but it can also help predict failure points in the part after molding. Cool stuff.

Another impressive experiment with polarizing filters is to have solutions of salts, solid organic acids, sugars and whatever evaporate on object glasses (the small slides used in a microscope). Sugars tend to crystalise extremely slowly. Then place one filter below the object glass (often there is a filter holder) an another somewhere above (perhaps you can cut up a pair of broken sunglasses and have a small disk on top of the occular - an old vertical microscope is easier to work with). Turn the filters so that the view is black and put an object glass in the microscope. Focus. Do not use a very high enlargement. Some crystals are not coloured but still rotates the light, so they appear ghostly (this is common of crystals of the cubic crystal system). Others non-cubic split the colours. It cannot be described. The shapes of the crystals is one thing the colours quite another.

This technique can be used with extremely thin slices of rocks to study the minerals in the rock and various irregularities.

Great video. 1 note, which is that polarizers don't truly "block" light in the way it's traditionally pictured. They set the polarization and can actually twist light by up to 45 degrees from the current setting. Minute physics and 3blue1brown did a really cool demonstration of this that uses 3 polarizers. Normally if you put 2 polarizers perpendicular you get blackness, but if you put a third in between them at 45 degrees, you twist the light enough that some can still make it through the third polarizer as it can then be twisted the remaining 45 degrees and get through.

This is pretty important for mineralogy. Anyone with a geology degree should have some exposure to optical mineralogy, which heavily uses a polarizing light microscope to look at thin sections of rock or mineral samples. These thin sections are typically 30 micrometers thick, so many minerals that usually appear opaque can actually allow light to pass through. (Some minerals actually are opaque, though)
Some of these minerals are isotropic, which (in this context) means that light has no preferred direction, so it doesn't get bent passing through them. Most minerals are anisotropic. (though the can appear isotropic if the light passing through just happens to be aligned with the axis around which the light bends, which comes from the crystal structure of the mineral) Anisotropic minerals display these colors, and what set of colors depends on how much the light is bent.

Something interesting to note is that most wireless routers (anything better than the cheapest ones) send and receive radio waves at different polarizations to encode more information into the same bandwidth. Going from one to two nearly doubles the bandwidth, while going even higher only gives incremental improvements since there can be only two polarizations that are orthogonal to each other. (That's why with a router that has external antennas, it's recommended to position the two outer antennas at 90 degrees from each other.)

A good visual analogy would be two projectors with orthogonal polarizations playing different videos at the same screen. Look at it directly and you only see a mix of the two videos, but look through a polarizer and by adjusting the angle, you can see just one or the other. (That is how some 3D display systems work.)

Hi Dianna. I love your show. I use many of your demos to teach my kids about the amazing world of science.

So here's a little trick I used to do that seems right up your alley. Can you boil water ... by adding cold? Anyone can boil water with heat - just fill a pan and put it on the stove. But take a clear glass jar with a tight sealing lid and fill it half-way up with water. Now boil it in the usual way - heat it on the stove until it comes to a vigorous boil. Then screw the lid on tight while it is still boiling (use hot pads to protect your hands). Let it cool down to room temperature. And finally put an ice pack on the top. before too long, you will get a lazy, languid boiling from the water trapped inside.

The explanation is simple. If the vapor pressure of a liquid exceeds the pressure on the liquid, bubbles can spontaneously form and expand. The vapor pressure increases as the temperature increases. So if you add heat from below, eventually the vapor pressure at the bottom exceeds the pressure from the surrounding air, and you get boiling in the normal manner. At this point, the vapor pressure is just a bit above the ambient atmospheric pressure, and pure water can exist as a gas at atmospheric pressure. So in the jar, the water vapor is pushing out all the nitrogen and oxygen and argon and stuff, until you get pure water vapor. When you seal the jar, air can't get back in and when it cools the water re-condenses leaving a partial vacuum whose only atmospheric component at any temperature is water vapor. When the vapor and liquid are at the same temperature, their vapor pressure is equal and no boiling occurs. But if you cool down the top, the water condenses and lowers the vapor pressure, allowing the higher vapor pressure of the water underneath to drive boiling. Cool!

Not only can you see polarization using Haidinger's Brush, but you can also determine the type and direction of the polarization. For linearly polarized light, the yellow axis of the Brush will be perpendicular to the plane of polarization. For circularly polarized light, the yellow axis will lean at an angle relative to the orientation of the viewer's head (instead of a fixed orientation for linear polarization), to the left for left-handed and to the right for right-handed.

I've used this same method to look at stresses on two different pieces of glass fused together. Glass expands differently based on what's in the glass and how it was made. If you do glass fusing to make art, you have to make sure the glass is compatible with each other. If not, temperature changes will eventually lead to the glass fracturing along the fuse point. Glass made specifically for fusing will list a Coefficient of Expansion (CoE) number specifically to assist this. (COE 90, 96 and 104 are some popular standards.) I don't know if this also is an issue for those doing torch work. If you melt and mix the glass in a furnace, that cuts out all compatibility issues.

Be sure to also rotate the first polarizer to see an entirely different set of patterns.  That changes the initial polarization direction entering the tape layers.  I believe that that when the tape is made through the extrusion process, the molecules get preferentially aligned along the length of the tape.  The rotation is caused by the fact that there are two optical axes (ordinary and extraordinary) where speed of light in the tape is different.  Different colors have slightly different speeds, so they get rotated by different amounts - hence the colors that show up after passing through the second polarizer.
